body: Good catch, thanks for reporting (and for trying the RC)!

This is due to a missing symlink check when updating files in the db (and not the transition that I commented on here:https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/commit/decb967969d164ef788b036791bcf9caa9209217#r39149359), which was there prior to 1.6.0, but only now has consequences...

Is anyone already working on this? I hope not, because I am now :P @AudriusButkevicius @calmh
So we can fix not creating them, and simply ignore (or delete) them on the read side for now?
We can't delete as the handling is in a readonly transaction. Probably a migration to cleanup? Or silence the warning?

This is rare enough that I think either just letting it be or silencing the warning. (I didnâ€™t check the code but how come we are even looking at this entry? I would expect to only look at entries matching some block hash?)

I also don't think it's worth it if that was just an edge case when updating or whatever. It also didn't show up after a restart so the entry probably got deleted by the non increasing sequence entry?
Btw I'm usually also using the git version which is probably a bad idea.
This entry does seem to have and match a blockhash... I guess an empty sha256?

I don't know if this is the source but I get
```[MP6JR] 2020/05/14 15:12:31.325761 model.go:1957: INFO: Repaired 1 sequence entries in database```
after I reset the whole database and started resyncing with the current master.

Do you mean you still get the warning about the unexpected type too? If not it might still be interesting to know why/under which circumstances it's repairing the sequence, but that would then be better done in the forum (and finally a separate issue, if it turns out to be a bug).

And when talking about master, please specify the commit - it's somewhat of a moving target otherwise ;)

No, I don't get the warning about the unexpected type. Yeah it's syncing really slow in general because one of the peers is a raspberry pi. I will wait a bit and if it doesn't get better I will create a forum post.

issue.title: panic: sequence index corruption

labels.name: bug
labels.description: A problem with current functionality, as opposed to missing functionality (enhancement)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

labels.name: skip-changelog
labels.description: Bugs that have never been in a released stable version, and as such excluded from the release notes

milestone.title: v1.6.0
milestone.description:
This release performs a database schema migration, and adds the `BlockPullOrder`, `DisableFsync` and `MaxConcurrentWrites` folder options to the configuration schema.

The `LocalChangeDetected` event no longer has the `action` set to `added` for new files, instead showing `modified` for all local file changes.

issue.body:
### Does your log mention database corruption?
yes

I don't know but I don't think this has something to do with hardware corruption.

### Include required information

Please be sure to include at least:

 - Arch Linux, Syncthing v1.6.0-rc.2+11-gf05ccd775, f05ccd775abf1a51a39b0363d72fe7942815e01b

Info: I'm also https://forum.syncthing.net/t/up-to-date-but-not-syncing/14998 and I also reported https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/issues/6637

### what happened
Some time after I checked e-mails with the latest Thunderbird release (I don't know when exactly) syncthing paniced but only at the laptop side not at the raspberry pi 3b. I think it also had the problem outlined in my forum post before but I'm not sure any more.

Logs: https://gist.github.com/mohe2015/126aa0fb81fe4a633fd829e1417ba1bc
More data can be provided on request. I won't reset the database for now (systemctls automatic restarts failed with the same panic) so I could also provide that if that can help.

### what you expected to happen instead
obviously not crashing

### any steps to reproduce the problem.
don't know, it was a fresh database with multiple gigabytes of data on two devices one of which is a laptop with an ssd and the other one is a raspberry pi 3b with a 64gb usb flash drive.

It could be possible that backing up .thunderbird may exhibit the problem.
